Using a condition as an index is similar to using subset , but there are some differences in behaviour, for example, in the way NAs are dealt with: > x <- c(2, 4, 6, 8, 1, 3, 5, 7, 9) > x[x > 5] [1] 6 8 7 9 > subset(x, x > 5) [1] 6 8 7 9 > y <- c(2, 4, 6, 8, NA, 1, 3, 5, 7, 9, NA) > y[y > 5] [1] 6 8 NA 7 9 NA > subset(y, y > 5) [1] 6 8 7 9 > x[NA] [1] NA NA NA NA NA NA NA NA NA > subset(x, NA) numeric(0) As for the question about multiple conditions, there is no reason why we can't have them as indices: > x[x > 3 & x < 7] [1] 4 6 5 > subset(x, x > 3 & x < 7) [1] 4 6 5

Thanks!

Input.threadtitle: [SOLVED] Wrong approach for counting missing values?
Input.posts:
One of the questions in the quiz for week one states: How many missing values are in the Ozone column of this data frame? To address this question I took the following steps: > data <- read.csv('hw1_data.csv') > ozone <- data$Ozone > length(ozone[is.na(x)]) [1] 44 The outcome is unexpected though, 44 is not in the list of accepted answers and manual counting of NA items after printing ozone gives me 37 which is one of the accepted answers. Any idea where I'm missing the boat here? Edit: Okay, the error was pretty obvious. I was apparently sleeping. is.na() should actually be passed the correct vector. So in this case the above could should have been changed to: > length(ozone[is.na(ozone)])
